reviewText: Sadly, I find myself not really sharing the same impressions of most of the professional critique.\nI have to say that in the last few years I've seen a lot of games like this one, and the problem is that they shouldn't have been games at all in my opinion. The story is ok(less great than what I was expecting from the reviews, though) but the problem is that you have to play through it. In this game, even walking from a room to another is a pain, the character walks unnaturally slow, I don't know why they chose to do so, maybe to add suspense, but it didn't work, at least not for me. You may think that this is something like a point and click game, but there's not one single decent puzzle in the entire game, making it really simple to complete. Sometimes you will have to find a combination for a certain lock, a code that you will easilly find written somewere, nothing that will need you to use the brain to be discovered, and those will be the hardest challenges in the game. Simply put, PLAYING this game is boring, and that will ruin the experience, no matter how great is the story. Probably it could be more entertaining watching someone else's playthroug on youtube, leaving him the boring part and enjoying the story better. This is something that the developers have to understand about this kind of games...if you don't have any clue about a gameplay to put on a good story, make a movie or something like that, not a game.

reviewText:
My first review of Gone Home was entirely positive. I supposed I focused mostly on the parents and the challenges they faced. It was a pleasant break from stealth-based horror titles and combat-centric games--a mundane mystery: where is everyone and why is the house empty?  Everything changed on my second playthrough scouring the house for every possible bit of information and with commentary enabled.  I started to see the cracks and little things that previously amused now annoy and/or disappoint.

I'd like to be clear on a few points before we begin again:  I've no problems with games that have zero combat, minimal gameplay, simple stories, independent-tier graphics,

Spoilers Ahead.  I mean it, the first point gives away the ending...


Let's jump into this headfirst:
Gone Home's central plot involves Kaitlin Greenbriar (the player) arriving at the family's new home (inheritted by her father, Terrance, from his Uncle Oscar) only to find that everyone's missing.  Samantha Greenbriar (the sister) provides occasional voice-overs as the player explores the house and discovers (through her sister's diary) that Samantha left with her lover, Lonnie, after their (Sam & Kate's) parents previously left on an anniversary vacation.

The complications that created this situation:

1 - Samantha becomes friends with Lonnie during their high school years and soon falls for her.  With biases towards sexual preferences being what they were in the 1990s, the pair face difficulty at school and further problems arise.  Samantha and Lonnie's relationship is conducted secretly until a forced exposure (truancy, low grades) to her parents.  They give Samantha the just a phase" speech before placing her on restriction.

2 - Lonnie Desoto comes from a military family
date: so naturally she prepares for a career in military service.  This places a wedge between her and Samantha as any thoughts to the future are accompanied with healthy amounts of doubt.\n\n3 - Terrence Greenbriar (the father) found success as a writer
recommended: but was dropped by his publisher after the second novel bombed.  After finding some unusual letters
hoursPlayed: I took a closer look at Oscar Masan (Terrence's uncle) and the suspicions began to pile up.  Oscar sexually abused Terrence.  This has been confirmed--long before I stumbled onto it--on the developer's Twitter profile.  Terrence's novels are attempts to find closure
voteText: but are also forcing him to relive the abuse (likely much worse in memory) and sleeping in the house where the assaults took place certainly isn't helping.\n\n4 - Meanwhile
helpfulPercent: Janice Greenbriar (the mother) has been growing more and more distant from Terrence and closer to her coworker
votesHelpful: Richard Something.\n\nEverything comes to a head when the parents leave on their vacation; whether Terrence has told Janice about his past abuse or if Richard's sudden engagement and marriage invitation forced her to remember her husband remains to be seen.  In their absence
votesTotal: Samantha has an opportunity to spend one more night with Lonnie before she ships out.  The night passes and Samantha wakes up alone.  Later she realizes Lonnie left her several messages indicating that she's changed her plans to enlist (...in spite of having a ship date?  That's desertion
votesFunny: madam.) and wants to spend her life with Samantha.\n\nSo that's the story
commentsCount: why has my recommendation changed?\n\nI was unaware of Terrence's abuse during my first playthrough.  I was convinced that Janice had given up her affair with Richard in order to rekindle her marriage.  Now it seems that the only options for them are Janice helping Terrence find closure or Janice adjusting to rejection and mending any bridges burned with her spouse.  The story's become darker with every subsequent look.  Oh
column16: well sideplots shouldn't affect the overall impression
column17: right?  Sure
column18: keep telling yourself that.\n\nPresent for some of the commentary was Corin Tucker...yeah
column19: don't worry I didn't know who she was either.  Apparently
column20: getting involved with feminism sells albums when the musician lacks the ability necessary.  Don't get me wrong:  the score was fine
column21: but the insert tracks were devoid of melody or meaning.  Corin Tucker's contribution to the commentary is largely self-promotion and the fiction that feminism is about equality for everyone.\n\nNot once during the commentary did anyone mention the parents.  Their story was what drew me in the most
column22:
but it seems those two characters are simply window dressing.  The backstory of Terrence and Oscar should have been at least mentioned  in the commentary.  Either the developers sold out during the game's promotion or they were dishonest from the start.

I haven't enjoyed writing this re-review.  It's been phenomenally disappointing to realize this game is not a positive message to everyone seeking love.  Would reactions to this game be the same if it were teenage boys instead of the two girls?  I doubt it.  Honest representations of alternative relationships are hard enough to find in games without added political propaganda.  I'll end this here while I still remember the good things Gone Home had to offer.

The Good:
- an honest portrayal of an alternative relationship without unnecessary melodrama
- mystery elements without stealth sequences
- solid minimal score
- excellent atmosphere

The Bad:
- annoying choices for insert music
column23:
but at least they're optional
- overpriced for the length of the game
- limited graphics options and some performance issues

The Ugly:
- deliberate propaganda at times
- restricts user access (One journal entry written by Samantha describes some very tame intimate contact between her and Lonnie and Kaitlin forces the player to drop the letter and refuses to pick it up again.  The developer points this out as if it were something to be proud of and not heavy-handed at all.  It implies female-female sexuality is in some way sacred compared to other relationships.)
- crashes on ending credits if the player attempts to skip"

reviewText:
I paid a little over $6 USD for this game it it was too much.  I knew what it was going into it, so it wasn't a content or gameplay issue.  It was a lack of content issue.  It's way too short.  I read everything and picked up everything and total gameplay was about two hours.

I also got to the end before I explored everything which annoyed me.  I had to go back after the credits to explore some rooms with possible clues in them.  The effect these clues were to have on me were ruined because I already knew how it ended.  It's like reading the last chapter of a book before you sequentially get there which ruins the story.

This game is too short for the $20 non-sale price.  The end is easily achievable before all clues are found leading to spoiled clues if you go back and find them.  How this was a Game of the Year" I will never understand.  Don't buy it unless it's only a couple of dollars."

It does what it does very well.. tells a story, but it stops there. This was not really fun to play, not exciting, just so flat. reviewText:
For me personally, I had high hopes, but was disappointed.

But lets get the good points; the sound track and the story of the younger sister. That's it. The graphics are okay, but nothing grand.

Now the rest; IT'S BORING!! Really, really, boring! There no other characters in the story so it feels empty, you can't really collect most the stuff even though you can pick it up or really do anything, so you'll just be throwing it like a spaz. For the most part you're just wandering around grabbing random stuff hoping to hear a voice. You don't even get a flashback or anything; just a voice. The atmosphere tries to trick you into thinking there's more going on, but after an hour of nothing it fades off.

Others seem to like but for me, it's not worth more than five dollars. If you want the best of the game, go to Youtube and find the soundtrack and a collaboration of the sister's tale; you'll get all the enjoyment without the useless wanders.

But again, it's just my opinion. At the very least, wait till it drops to five bucks. (Maybe less)

reviewText:
This game, by NO MEANS, deserves the positive ratings and publicity it has received such as the praise from the NY Times.  Any game that can be completed in minutes and at MOST takes an hour to complete is a ripoff.  The positive publicity for this was clearly bought in their favor.

Problems:
Too Short
Lame concept
Not worth the current price tag
Adventures like this were cute back in the day, but there needs to be more substance in a game released after 2010.

Praises:
Didn't crash
Ran decently (though, I must mention that the scenes where you can see rain on the windows had severe slowdown issues I've never experienced in other games)

Many American people today accept non-heterosexual affiliations.  This game doesn't make a life changing point.  Maybe if this were published back in the 90's when the game is supposed to take place it would've been more meaningful.  We all know that homosexuality was looked down upon in the past, but most people have their priorities straight by now.

reviewText:
I wish there was a sideways thumb for this title. I am a lover of spooky horror games and I feel like this had potential but managed to miss the mark for me a bit. While I thought the journal entries with the LGBT theme were a very sweet and endearing part of the story, I felt like it detracted from the spookiness a lot. It ended up sounding less like a scary story and more like an oppressed teen running away with her girlfriend. Made me wonder what the point of the whole thing was.

The atmosphere was decent as far as 'horror' games go. In the end, I had a hard time figuring out what the big mystery was. Exploration was fun at first but then quickly became sort of tedious as I meticulously gone through every room and encountered a locked door that I couldn't open. After searching the entire house without finding a way to progress, I decided I didn't want to spend any more time on this title.

I really don't like when games are arbitrarily long with no substantial filling. You can't just hide a key in a giant house where nothing is happening except the sound of thunder. Even all the lights work properly, so you don't have to be scared in the dark. There are seemingly useful bits of information everywhere but half of them are useless filler.  They didn't explain anything or help me figure out how to progress in the story. Most of it was random drivel.

So if this game is supposed to be scary, FAIL! If the game is supposed to be a new exploration/mystery type genre, not so fail, but deff not for me.

reviewText: THIS IS LES BOS
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This isn't the easiest game to describe, let alone review.
Some nitpicky people will even try to tell you it's not a game at all, since there's no way to die/fail/lose.
There's only one level, only one thing you work towards, and then it's over. A mere 3 hours in (for me personally).

That can't be good, can it?
It is. It so is.

The player controls Kaitlin Greenbriar who, after a of travelling abroad, has Gone Home.
Her homecoming isn't quite as she'd planned it though, since nobody appears to be there to greet her.
What follows is an exploration of a large house, its history, what your family has been up to in the year that you weren't there, and why nobody is there.

This exploration is done very literally, you roam through the house in a first person perspective and look at things that you find. Almost everything can be picked up and analysed, most of it won't progress the game along (should you choose you can spend half an hour looking at a pack of toilet paper from all angles). What this accomplishes is that the house you wander around in feels very real. It's not laid out like a videogame level (mostly anyway), it actually feels like a home.

Some objects spark memories, either Kaitlin's or those of her younger sister, Samantha. The protagonist's are displayed along the bottom of the screen, but Samantha's are fully voiced, generally taking the form of diary entries. The voice acting is believable, emotional, endearing.

The game tells you a story, primarily Samantha's, of how Kaitlin being away has impacted her life, what she's been up to, how she handled moving to a new house, how she's making new friends. Endearing is a word I've used already in this review, several times maybe even, but that's what the game makes you do. You care about Samantha, and every diary excerpt you uncover makes you care a little bit more.

By the time you've finally made your way to the last room to explore (game progress is generally non-linear except for two or three segments where you have to know a trick that is only explained in Samantha's diary entries to gain entry to a new part of the house) you'll be hooked and want to know the conclusion.

And I loved the conclusion. The entire game builds up to it so well, both foreshadowing and alluding, and it's amazing feat of storytelling.
Treat yourself and play this game, but expect to be told a story and explore a house, not to have your reflexes challenged.
Definitely, passionately and endearingly recommended.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

Her homecoming isn't quite as she'd planned it though, since nobody appears to be there to greet her.
What follows is an exploration of a large house, its history, what your family has been up to in the year that you weren't there, and why nobody is there.

This exploration is done very literally, you roam through the house in a first person perspective and look at things that you find. Almost everything can be picked up and analysed, most of it won't progress the game along (should you choose you can spend half an hour looking at a pack of toilet paper from all angles). What this accomplishes is that the house you wander around in feels very real. It's not laid out like a videogame level (mostly anyway), it actually feels like a home.

Some objects spark memories, either Kaitlin's or those of her younger sister, Samantha. The protagonist's are displayed along the bottom of the screen, but Samantha's are fully voiced, generally taking the form of diary entries. The voice acting is believable, emotional, endearing.

The game tells you a story, primarily Samantha's, of how Kaitlin being away has impacted her life, what she's been up to, how she handled moving to a new house, how she's making new friends. Endearing is a word I've used already in this review, several times maybe even, but that's what the game makes you do. You care about Samantha, and every diary excerpt you uncover makes you care a little bit more.

By the time you've finally made your way to the last room to explore (game progress is generally non-linear except for two or three segments where you have to know a trick that is only explained in Samantha's diary entries to gain entry to a new part of the house) you'll be hooked and want to know the conclusion.

And I loved the conclusion. The entire game builds up to it so well, both foreshadowing and alluding, and it's amazing feat of storytelling.
Treat yourself and play this game, but expect to be told a story and explore a house, not to have your reflexes challenged.
Definitely, passionately and endearingly recommended.

reviewText: I really liked this game at first. I LOVED it at first. But, now, I don't think I do anymore. It had a pretty compelling story when I first started. You knew everything that was gonna happen. Also, it's really short. I have beaten the game 3 times to find all the creepy aspects of it and only have 3.4 hours. But, you find out in the first 5-10 minutes where your sister is. It is way to predictible. I really wanted to recommend this game but...it's just too predictible and there isn't much here. I can't wait to see what else comes from this company but their first game just didn't do it for me.

reviewText: Many players have touted Gone Home to be a breakthrough in using interactive media to deliver an interesting narrative.  I felt like it was similar to any action-based game driven by story, with all the action stripped out.  Imagine going around a house and picking up notes to read.  The construct around the discovery of these notes, when you break it down, is fairly impressive.  The player is given the story in non-chronological order, and the game is able to tie the disjoint information together nicely.  Ultimately though, the story itself does not feel substantial or have enough gravitas to make the trip worth it.

reviewText:
Grade: 60/100
Difficulty: Can you navigate with WASD and click a mouse? Can you read beyond a 4th grade level?
Pros: There are lots of details, and I am jealous of anyone who owns THAT many books and records. There are also some nice 90's references for those of us who grew up in that decade.
Cons: The atmosphere makes you feel like something is going to jump out at you at any moment -- but nothing ever does. There is the occasional thunder and a few of the lights flicker a little. But otherwise it's just you and your snooping about the house. Listening to any of the cassette tapes you find is something you do at your own risk. The vocals will make your ears bleed.
Replayable: No, because the story is not worth it. In fact, the story is what ruined this game for me. It focuses heavily on the younger sister, who is just your average unhappy teenager who falls in with the ever-in-trouble rebel at school -- and ultimately leads to terrible life decisions and a hugely anticlimactic ending. Do not waste your money on this game unless it is at least 75% off -- you will feel cheated otherwise.

reviewText: First off, this game isn't for everyone. It has no action or puzzles and in a sense is basically a walking simulator. For those of you who do not like interactive story games, DO NOT buy this game! For those of you who do, continue reading below. I will also warn whomever is reading this that this review will be quite lengthy, but will hopefully help you decide whether or not this game is for you.\n\nI do not play many indie games, so when I saw this game for sale on Steam I thought I would give it a try. You play as a girl named Katie who comes home from a year long trip in Europe to find her house empty. The basis of the game is to explore" the house and to find out what happened to your family. I say explore rather sarcastically
date: because even though you have to hunt for clues around the house
recommended: the game is very linear and you are forced to follow a set path. The game itself is also VERY short. I took my time to explore the house and I still clocked in at only about 2 hours at the end of the game. You can look it up online but you can literally beat this game in less than one minute if you know what to look for. So for a $20 price tag
hoursPlayed: this game is akin to highway robbery and even at a discounted price it is tough to justify.\n\nNow the story itself I mildly enjoyed. First off
voteText: the "main" story revolves around your sister Sam
helpfulPercent: who turns out to be a lesbian very early on in the story. I personally don't mind the LGBT themes in movies and games
votesHelpful: as long as they are not shoehorned in (which usually indicates some sort of agenda versus good storytelling). This game kinda toed the line in that regard
votesTotal: as I actually started to laugh as they made the not so subtle reveal. There are also other storylines that are put in the game for some reason but are not fully fleshed out
votesFunny: leaving the player to wonder why they were ever in the game in the first place. The most prominent example are the whole "exercism" and "psycho house" themes. Now while I realize the developers have said that there is no violence or horror in this game and it is just about exploration
commentsCount: it seems counter-intuitive to create a dark and forboding environment if they were not going to fully utilize it. I really did like how a lot of the story was told by the clues left around the house like letters and notes
column16: and piecing the story together for yourself. I'll also mention that while some of the nostalgia themes from the 1990's were appreciated (I personally enjoyed the numerous X-Files references)
column17: the fact that this game is set in that time period really has no effect on the story whatsoever.\n\nTo sum it all up
column18: I liked this game. However
column19: the underdeveloped story and characters and the extremely short playtime are too big of faults to overlook. Add in the fact that there is no replayablility to this game and the $20 price tag and you have a recipe for disaster. I am glad I did not pay full price for this game and I can guarantee you this review would be drastically different if I had. If you see this game on sale for a dollar or two
column20: I'd say give it a try
column21: but at the end of the day you really aren't missing anything by passing it up."

reviewText: First off, this game isn't for everyone. It has no action or puzzles and in a sense is basically a walking simulator. For those of you who do not like interactive story games, DO NOT buy this game! For those of you who do, continue reading below. I will also warn whomever is reading this that this review will be quite lengthy, but will hopefully help you decide whether or not this game is for you.\n\nI do not play many indie games, so when I saw this game for sale on Steam I thought I would give it a try. You play as a girl named Katie who comes home from a year long trip in Europe to find her house empty. The basis of the game is to explore" the house and to find out what happened to your family. I say explore rather sarcastically
date: because even though you have to hunt for clues around the house
recommended: the game is very linear and you are forced to follow a set path. The game itself is also VERY short. I took my time to explore the house and I still clocked in at only about 2 hours at the end of the game. You can look it up online but you can literally beat this game in less than one minute if you know what to look for. So for a $20 price tag
hoursPlayed: this game is akin to highway robbery and even at a discounted price it is tough to justify.\n\nNow the story itself I mildly enjoyed. First off
voteText: the "main" story revolves around your sister Sam
helpfulPercent: who turns out to be a lesbian very early on in the story. I personally don't mind the LGBT themes in movies and games
votesHelpful: as long as they are not shoehorned in (which usually indicates some sort of agenda versus good storytelling). This game kinda toed the line in that regard
votesTotal: as I actually started to laugh as they made the not so subtle reveal. There are also other storylines that are put in the game for some reason but are not fully fleshed out
votesFunny: leaving the player to wonder why they were ever in the game in the first place. The most prominent example are the whole "exercism" and "psycho house" themes. Now while I realize the developers have said that there is no violence or horror in this game and it is just about exploration
commentsCount: it seems counter-intuitive to create a dark and forboding environment if they were not going to fully utilize it. I really did like how a lot of the story was told by the clues left around the house like letters and notes
column16: and piecing the story together for yourself. I'll also mention that while some of the nostalgia themes from the 1990's were appreciated (I personally enjoyed the numerous X-Files references)
column17: the fact that this game is set in that time period really has no effect on the story whatsoever.\n\nTo sum it all up
column18: I liked this game. However
column19: the underdeveloped story and characters and the extremely short playtime are too big of faults to overlook. Add in the fact that there is no replayablility to this game and the $20 price tag and you have a recipe for disaster. I am glad I did not pay full price for this game and I can guarantee you this review would be drastically different if I had. If you see this game on sale for a dollar or two
column20: I'd say give it a try
column21: but at the end of the day you really aren't missing anything by passing it up."

reviewText:
This game made me want to be a teenage girl again.  AND I'M A FORTY YEAR OLD MAN.

Is it wrong that I nearly cried at the end of this game (and a couple of times during)?  DOES IT MAKE ME LESS OF A MAN THAT I RELATE TO THE FEELINGS OF MESSED-UP TEENAGE GIRLS?!  This game covers it all...sexual confusion, familial disfunction, first loves...even a possible haunting and/or demonic possession (do your research).  If you are a male who wants to understand young women better, PLAY THIS GAME.  And for that matter, if you're an aspiring game designer who wants some idea of how a tell a story, and how a perfectly-structured adventure game should slowly and logically unveil its secrets, you might also learn something.  Hell, even aspiring novelists or film-makers could probably learn something from this one.  MICHAEL ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING BAY SHOULD BE REQUIRED BY LAW TO PLAY THIS GAME AT LEAST THREE TIMES BEFORE HE'S PERMITTED TO MAKE ANOTHER MOVIE!!!

That is all, class dismissed.

Verdict: 9.5/10.

reviewText:
A great novel for the demographic for which it is intended (the LGBT crowd), this novel is too short and too expensive to be worth buying.

First off, 2 hours is the average completion time of this novel.  In my play of it, I searched every room, picked up every object, and read every readable piece of paper; all of this, I did in 2 hours.  2 hours is not worth $20.  Only the most popular of movies can get people to fork over $10 to see them on the big screen, and this novel is no blockbuster. This novel, while WELL paced, is for girls with an interest in gay/bisexual relationships--take note this is not a bad thing: Although consumers interested in the game should be aware of this fact in case this kind of topic may turn them off from playing such a novel.

Linearly designed, using door keys to block ways, the novel leads you down a straight path.  Yes, there are many rooms and hallways to inspect, but inevitably you will go down specific ones required for you to beat the game.  The only choice the user has is how much time the user wishes to spend looking at things other than the story-required ones.  After examining and using story-required objects the novel opens the next branch of the map.  While this disallows replayability, it is atmospheric and immerses the user into the story well.  It does become repetitive, however.

It is a walking simulator (not an inherently bad thing), which means the majority of interaction is walking and looking at things.  You will pick up things and toss them down, and that is how complex it gets, which for a lot of people is quite refreshing.  This simplicity allows the novel to remain casual and not a brain teaser.  The story is not complicated either.  It tells an easy to understand story about girls becoming curious about their sexual orientation, discovering it, and then the user learns about the struggles that come with such a life.



In conclusion, It is a fantastic visual novel for those who dig the story.  Sadly, it is not long, nor replayable.  It feels more like chapter 1 of a longer novel.  For someone interested in female gay/bisexual relationships, wait until a Steam sale to buy this for about $5.  For those who are not interested in an LGBT story, this novel is not for you.  It is no GOTY because it short, expensive, and has a small demographic intended to play it.  For these reasons I cannot recommend this novel.

For other interactive visual novels, I suggest looking at Dear Esther and Stanley's Parable.  Both of those are admittedly short as well, but they tell interesting stories as well.  I cannot recommend them, either, at their normal prices, but during a sale they are certainly bargains.  So if you like interactive novels you may like them too.

reviewText:
TL;dr: this isn't a survival/horror. It's a commentary on social issues that happens to be in a spooky house.

I really liked this game in the beginning. The house, the environment feels rich and authentic. It, simply put, was spooky in a way I hadn't experienced since playing the 7th Guest. Which is awesome. The detail of the items, the feel of the home as a 'freshly moved in' place is extraordinarily well done. Everything is believable and thought out. Little details everywhere reinforce the multiple characters and stories in Gone Home. For the small team that put this together, they should be proud of their work; it is an excellent environment for exploration.

As for the story and the game itself.. well... as the game progressed, and the plot" played out
date: the whole experience.. thinned out. Suddenly I wasn't alone in a spooky house
recommended: I was alone being fed snippets of a story that did not relate directly to me
hoursPlayed: as a player.\n\nTowards the end
voteText: it slowly dawned on me that this was not a survival/horror (which
helpfulPercent: to be fair
votesHelpful: I supposed it is not marketed as?) It felt like I started off in a genuinely spooky movie
votesTotal: but ended up in a Lifetime Original. It just felt like I had come in expecting one thing
votesFunny: and about three quarters the way through I realized that the spookiness and eerieness of the game were just incidental. Which totally sapped the suspense out of the rest of the game.\n\nThat said
commentsCount: I have nothing against the main story (or message
column16: if you will) of this game. I think it addresses important issues
column17: and is genuine and feels real. But in the context of this game
column18: it just feels out of place. Maybe I've played too many games and feel entitled to a certian consistency in gameplay? It is
column19: after all
column20: the developer's right to take a game in any direction they like.\n\nI feel like the dev team started with a great idea
column21: wasn't sure how to wrap it all together
column22: and chose to make a social statement rather than continue to work in the direction they started in. But
column23: that's MY feelings

reviewText:
Having a hard time recommending this one.  If you really want something different and quick (1.5 hrs) then this is for you, but if you want something thats more of a traditional game then this ain't gonna cut it.

They advertise the game as being a story exploration video game and thats exactly what it is.  You come home from a long trip and you walk around the house finding clues to your family's whereabouts.  You move room to room finding notes and getting a feel for what this family is like until you reach the end of the story. There are no puzzles to solve so the story kind of just tells itself as you enter each area of the house and the story is as simple as the gameplay.

The game of the year awards aren't too surprising because the game should be recognized but don't expect anythng stellar.  Although I haven't played The Stanley Parable, based on the demo, I'd recommend that over Gone Home if you want a more entertaining story exploration experience.

reviewText:
This game is linear, dull, anticlimactic, melodramatic, boring and short.

Avoid at all costs. However much steam discounts it for, it is not worth it. If it was *free* I'd ask for a refund and happily wipe it forever from my hard drive, which I am on my way to do now. I'd rather have the a 670~ MB taken up by a notepad document with nothing but ascii wangs repeated over and over. At least that would make me smile when I looked at it. Unlike this game, a relentless, dull, atmosphere-free, linear slog through repetive opening of drawers with terrible pacing.

0/10

reviewText:
This game is overrated.

Groping in the dark for light switches is the worst. gameplay mechanic. ever.

Sure, you figure out parts of the story from note you read, and that's kinda cool, but most of it is fed to you from the sister's point of view anyways. There is not really much deduction to do. And despite what others may say, the story isn't all that good either.

The only part worth appreciating about this game is how much detail is on all the crap lying around. The soda cans, toilet paper, and books all have an authentic feel. but that's it. nothing else worth seeing in the game.

reviewText:
not a game.

i'm not trying to make a statement about the 'is it a game?' topic that happens a lot with these kinds of things.  art, game, story, whatever.  this, this is not a game.

this is not fun.  i'm sure it's smart, and i'm sure it has an emotional impact.

but you don't play it!  it isn't fun to play!  i am not being entertained.

if i want to learn, or feel things, i will read a book.  i like reading books, i read a lot of them.

i play games so i can experience exotic locales, have dangerous adventures, overcome obstacles.

if i want to root through an abandoned house i'll GO BACK TO ROBBING HOUSES LIKE I USED TO before i started using video games to curb my recidivistic tendencies.

i'm sure this is awesome, but i don't care.

reviewText:
A great novel for the demographic for which it is intended (the LGBT crowd), this novel is too short and too expensive to be worth buying.

First off, 2 hours is the average completion time of this novel.  In my play of it, I searched every room, picked up every object, and read every readable piece of paper; all of this, I did in 2 hours.  2 hours is not worth $20.  Only the most popular of movies can get people to fork over $10 to see them on the big screen, and this novel is no blockbuster. This novel, while WELL paced, is for girls with an interest in gay/bisexual relationships--take note this is not a bad thing: Although consumers interested in the game should be aware of this fact in case this kind of topic may turn them off from playing such a novel.

Linearly designed, using door keys to block ways, the novel leads you down a straight path.  Yes, there are many rooms and hallways to inspect, but inevitably you will go down specific ones required for you to beat the game.  The only choice the user has is how much time the user wishes to spend looking at things other than the story-required ones.  After examining and using story-required objects the novel opens the next branch of the map.  While this disallows replayability, it is atmospheric and immerses the user into the story well.  It does become repetitive, however.

It is a walking simulator (not an inherently bad thing), which means the majority of interaction is walking and looking at things.  You will pick up things and toss them down, and that is how complex it gets, which for a lot of people is quite refreshing.  This simplicity allows the novel to remain casual and not a brain teaser.  The story is not complicated either.  It tells an easy to understand story about girls becoming curious about their sexual orientation, discovering it, and then the user learns about the struggles that come with such a life.



In conclusion, It is a fantastic visual novel for those who dig the story.  Sadly, it is not long, nor replayable.  It feels more like chapter 1 of a longer novel.  For someone interested in female gay/bisexual relationships, wait until a Steam sale to buy this for about $5.  For those who are not interested in an LGBT story, this novel is not for you.  It is no GOTY because it short, expensive, and has a small demographic intended to play it.  For these reasons I cannot recommend this novel.

For other interactive visual novels, I suggest looking at Dear Esther and Stanley's Parable.  Both of those are admittedly short as well, but they tell interesting stories as well.  I cannot recommend them, either, at their normal prices, but during a sale they are certainly bargains.  So if you like interactive novels you may like them too.

reviewText: I wanted to like this game.  I tried to convince myself even after I beat the game that it was worth the purchase.  But, after some reflection, I just wasn't into this game.  I usually love adventure games and exploration type games, but I was hoping for more to the story.  The pay off just didn't seem worth the build up.  I think I was expecting more of a mystery and more drama.  Unfortunately with adventure games, if you aren't into the story, the game just isn't worth while.  I would've also liked the game to be a bit longer than an hour and a half.\n\nTo sum it up, the graphics look pretty good, the story just didn't resonate with me, and the gameplay was typical adventure point and click.

reviewText:
You are not the protagonist, and Gone Home is not your story.

In most games, the players write their own stories: their actions and struggles define the game plot. Not so in Gone Home: this game asks you to explore the stories of other people (your family, mostly, including the psycho great-uncle Oscar). Your impact on these people is zero, because during the game, they're not home. Also, their stories are hidden: you need to find it in odds and ends strewn around the house, and even if you find them all, there'll be a lot left to the imagination (provided you have any).

If you're a narcisstic person with no emotional intelligence, this game will leave you cold because it won't be about you, but about other poeple's feelings. If you aren't, you'll enjoy a good teenie chick-flick" story told from a very different angle. If you're a child of the nineties
date: it's worth it for amount of love and detail that went into the whole house alone. Rarely have I wandered through a game and felt so immersed."

reviewText:
Gone Home puts you in the shoes of Kaitlin, a girl who has just come back from a long trip in Europe to find that nobody is home. As you approach the door you find a cryptic note written by your sister, Sam, saying that she has gone and to not come looking for her. The game involves you wandering around a mansion which your family moved into while you were away looking for clues as to her whereabouts.

I really enjoyed playing Gone Home. I found the story to be compelling and it was a lot of fun interacting with the different objects around the house.

reviewText:
The game is in the year 1995, in 1995 my dad had a cellphone at work, he was a janitor it wasn't that uncommon to have phones, and no one in this family that lives in a mansion and can afford to let their kid go on holiday for a year to Europe has one? Or notepads  made of paper for leaving messages in the hallway like a normal person? It felt like a bit of a stretch that there was no actual message from anyone waiting for her telling her anything about anything when the game starts, they where after all expecting her home, suspension of disbelief I guess...

Also turn the thunder off for ****s sake... it got annoying after the 5th one let alone the 50th or 500th, I actually though it took away from the playing experience.

Other then that an okay walking and read and look game if you into that kinda thing, nothing special though. Play it if you bored and don't feel like reading an actual book. I'd give it a neutral if I could, but since I can't it gets a no.

I took my time and looked at everything and I'd played for 2.8 hours when I finished, it can probably be finished alot quicker if you don't lift, click and read everything. (I then ran the game a little longer for the 3rd card to drop.)

reviewText: Looking at reviews of this game, I was expecting a bit of a suspenseful adventure game that involved more exploration than combat. Perhaps I didn't do my homework enough. I got suspense, but it turned out to be false. There was no danger the whole time, but instead a somewhat hokey monologued love story instead. Every corner of the empty ominous house filled me with dread, only to find those feelings in the end were for absolutely nothing; it's just an empty house.\n\nThis game is getting appraise from indie gamers and hipster game critics alike for its subject matter and off-the-beaten-path (read: explore and examine items) gameplay style. Disregard this. If you want this sort of game, go buy Dear Esther immediately and get a much spookier, better written, more beautiful and engaging game. People seem to go nuts about Gone Home for the way it approaches story, but as a long time adventure gamer, I came out of this very disappointed I even spent $10 on it. You spend a little under two hours going through a deserted house reading scrawled notes and throwing every item out of drawers, making a mess of the place. If you really want to see what the fuss is about, wait til it drops to $2.50 or less. Otherwise, get a Telltale game, Dear Esther, or virtually any other adventure game on Steam for a better experience. Stay away from this one or proceed with caution. 5.5/10.

reviewText:
I DON‚ÄôT RECOMMEND THIS GAME AT FULL PRICE

BUY ONLY AT 75% OFF.

Gone home is a first person exploration game. Well maybe it‚Äôs not a game but more of an experience. There are no puzzles, no challenge and nothing to put your game skills to test here. This ‚Äúgame‚Äù is all about exploring a house, looking at items and basically learning more about the people who live in the house and their background.  Without spoiling the story because this is the ‚Äú meat‚Äù of the game I will have to say that it tries to create an emotional connection with the user but the problem here is that THIS connection is hard to be established on all people who play the game and it depends on their own norms/values. That is also the reason that some people like the game and others don't. Furthermore this game is full of Easter eggs. If you were born in the 80‚Äôs just like me you will find a lot of references here. Some items will bring back memories from your childhood. The ‚Äúgame‚Äù is all about creating nostalgia but nonetheless it covers a very sensitive topic.

Personally the story for ME was not very touching and to tell the truth I enjoyed exploring the house in order to find those 80‚Äôs and early 90‚Äôs easter eggs. The main story was average and predictable to say the least.

Pros: beautiful environment that looks and feels like a real house, lots of Easter eggs, 80‚Äôs nostalgia is everywhere,  good voice work, the soundtrack is excellent and the music fits with the tone of the game

Cons: main story it‚Äôs predictable and boring, there is no real gameplay here, no replayability, the game is only 2 hours long and it‚Äôs also very expensive for its duration.

FINAL SCORE: 6.5/10

I give thumps down just because there is no middle ground in the rating system and because I recommend this game only during sales just for the nostalgia.

reviewText:
I'm not sure if I dislike this game so much because of all the glowing reviews it got, but this seems like gamings equivalent of Oscar bait.
The environment of the game is just one house. I find this a very interesting and challenging design choice. However, it seems to rely way too much on nostalgia from a period I personally was not alive in. Many praise it for this, but I see it as a somewhat weak trigger.

At first glance, it seems like a horror game. This means I played the game in completely the wrong mood, seeing as the shallow story that is actually underlying it really has nothing to do with horror. The story is nicely voice-overed, but seems at many times designed just to cause feelings from, again, reviewers, who have been pushing this social justice thing a lot lately. While I am all for diversity in gaming, it does not excuse lazy design and shallow storytelling. Was the game to be about a boy and a girl, which would honestly work just well, I doubt it would receive the amount of praise it did.

I highly applaud the game for its experimenting in storytelling, but I cannot say that I believe it pulled it off well at all. The reviews got me in the wrong mindset, and I would probably have enjoyed it much more if it weren't for them.

I'm feeling a strong 5

reviewText: Gone Home is beautiful. The less you know about it before playing it, the better your experience is going to be, and while I think it has one glaring flaw (the way the rooms are laid out in the house is nonsensical and drew me out of the experience a little, it's so obviously a level made to funnel you through things in the right order, no one would lay a real house out like that) the overall experience is perfect. Gone Home is one of the best displays we've seen of what games have the potential to be, not pretty visual effects but poignant stories as they could only be told through this medium. Not to be missed, though I'd recommend grabbing it on sale. Even for all my praise, $20 is overpricing for a game that lasts about three hours.

reviewText: Alright, so the game is usually $19.99, but for the Winter 2015 sale it is $5.99. I purchased this game a while back at around $4.99 (iirc) and am now just getting to review it.\n\nIt is certainly not worth $19.99. reviewText:
For a game that was highly recommended to me, and having seen it rated as ‚ÄòIndie Game of the Year‚Äô, I thought I couldn't go wrong by getting it. Unfortunately, I was sorely disappointed by it. It‚Äôs a shame because I did actually quite enjoy the game ‚Äì up until it ended (much too soon), and I was left feeling dissatisfied.

It‚Äôs unfortunate because the rooms in the house were beautifully made, and it really did make you feel like you were exploring a real family‚Äôs house, with lots of backstory and substance. There were some cool mechanics (like ‚Äòput back‚Äô), and the sound and interaction did really immerse you. But the actual story felt severely lacking and, frankly, quite mediocre. All of the atmosphere that had been built up lead nowhere, and I was left with many unanswered questions and devoid of any accomplishment by the end.

It took me a mere 70 minutes to complete, and I didn‚Äôt feel that I was rushing through it. Fortunately, I had purchased the game for just $4.99 on Humble Bundle, but if I had paid the full price of ¬£14.99, I would feel really ripped off.

I went into this game with absolutely no prior knowledge, and I guess I didn‚Äôt really know what to expect from it, but I was expecting something more, and it never delivered.

reviewText:
Gone Home isn't a game. It is a story in game format. And it wouldn't work on any other medium. The story and mysteries presented are nice and they leave some space for interpretation. After the story is over, there really isn't any replay value. It would be like reading a book for a second time.

There is little to do besides finding clues and putting pieces of the story together. You wander around the house, take items in your hands, turn them around and put them back or toss them away.

Gone Home isn't completely void of positive sides. It excels at creating an atmosphere. This is exactly what it feels like to roam around a strange house. I was constantly waiting for a jumpscare.

If you really enjoy stories or if you have played" Dear Esther or Trauma and enjoyed it
date: Gone Home is a game for you. Otherwise

reviewText:
This, believe it or not, is not actually a game. This is actually art that poorly desguises itself as a game.

Imagine, if you will, that you return home from a several month long trip touring the globe only to find your mansion sized house totally empty. What do you do? You follow bread crumbs through this monolithic house with solid wood doors thicker than a baseball in every room, breadcrumbs left by your sister. However, teh placement of these bread crumbs is random, some pinned to lockers, some in drawers, and some in secret passages in the walls. Somehow, through an act of God almighty himself, you find these breadcrumbs in exactally the right order to get the full story of how your sister discovered she was a lesbian and ran away with her lover, who goes MIA the first day of army bootcamp to be with her.

Is this not enough for you? Is this twenty minute game, which claims to be worth a dollar a minute, not satisfying enough? Well then, your in luck, because for thirty seconds there's a somewhat intruiging ghost story sub-plot that contains a single jumpscare, and then is manages to make you stop caring entirely by never mentioning it again. Still not enough? well then, prepare to wonder where your parents are at 12:00 at night during a thunderstorm only a few days after their youngest daughter dissappears. be astounded as this mystery is never answered and the game ends with a not-so-dramatic narration.

I'm being totally honest here, it's an alright game/ art/ cultural criticism thingy, but not nearly worth 20$ i've finished this game four times and I still only have 1.3 hours logged. I feel the pnly reason this game got such great reviews is because it has a lesbian love story as its primary motivation to finish the game, and no one wants to look like an intolerant ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• when it comes to sexuality. That and the hipsters jumped on it, and no one wants to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• off the hipsters.

In short, buy this game on sale for 2$, not for 20$. If you want drama go play the walking dead and the wolf amoung us.

reviewText:
(SPOILERS AHEAD)
I'm not going to critique the narrative in the game, because it's a neat concept, but not neat enough to warrant paying $20 for it (nor neat enough to warrant it being a game). This should have just been a short story instead.

When it comes to gameplay (or lack there of), it's just walking and reading. Walking Simulator 2014 basically. This isn't fun in the least. There is NO replayability in the slightest. Not to mention that the game is roughly an hour and a half long. This should have either been a free game, or (like previously mentioned) a short story.

Another thing, the game seemed to be playing off of the Survival Horror demographic. Yes, I know it's not Survival Horror, but it's in an empty house with flickering/moody lights. It plays to the demographic, without giving anything close to a game that demographic would enjoy.

I can summarize the plot of this game in one sentence:

Your sister is a lesbian
date: and she left home with her girlfriend."\n\nThat's it

Gone Home isn't a game. It's a bore.

1/10"

reviewText:
Gone Home is a barely a video game and is more like a student project demonstrating a bright new idea rather than an offering that should be up on the Steam Store, let alone up for twenty dollars.

At its heart, Gone Home experiments with story telling through simple narration and the placement of items.  The stories focus on the protagonist's sister (Sam), her sweetheart, and their upcoming separation as one prepares for college and the other for Basic Combat Training in the US Army.  Their story is told through notes and letters, through narration from the sister, and through the occasional concert stub or band poster.  The protagonist's parents each have a less-developed narrative arc which is told entirely through the things they own and the correspondance they receive.

In a way, I would love to sit down the devs of many modern games, point to Gone Home, and say, That is how you tell narrative with setting!  That is how you write a story of attraction and romance!"  These two aspects are well done
date: and the level of attention and fidelity to minor details show just how much you can show about your characters just by things like the state of their rooms
hoursPlayed: and the clothes they own.  You can learn more about Sam in five minutes glancing about her room than in ten hours of awkward dialog.\n\nDespite this one striking feature
voteText: ultimately the love story is not enough to support this game.  It's a well-told story
helpfulPercent: but one you will not want to hear a second or maybe third time.  Nor will you want to explore the house again; having seen the contents once
votesHelpful: you will have seen them all.  Suddenly
votesTotal: the one-time trip to explore the house becomes the tedium of doing something rote.  The game advertises there's no puzzles and no combat
votesFunny: and while that makes for an interesting experience one time
commentsCount: once you've picked up a few dozen ticket stubs

column17: and books

column19: is there?\n\nHowever

column21: but the stories for your parents are "hidden."  Their tales come out only for a player who pays attention to the clues in the environment.  It's not a great mystery requiring Poirot-like leaps of logic to solve
column22: but it does showcase a beautiful example of how background details can be left in the background and the player can be trusted to find them.  Nowadays
column23: when most games feel a need to focus the player like a laser on ever aspect
column24: it's a nice touch.  It's also a beautiful example storytelling without dialog and without words.  No one is ever seen in the house

reviewText:
(SPOILERS AHEAD)
I'm not going to critique the narrative in the game, because it's a neat concept, but not neat enough to warrant paying $20 for it (nor neat enough to warrant it being a game). This should have just been a short story instead.

When it comes to gameplay (or lack there of), it's just walking and reading. Walking Simulator 2014 basically. This isn't fun in the least. There is NO replayability in the slightest. Not to mention that the game is roughly an hour and a half long. This should have either been a free game, or (like previously mentioned) a short story.

Another thing, the game seemed to be playing off of the Survival Horror demographic. Yes, I know it's not Survival Horror, but it's in an empty house with flickering/moody lights. It plays to the demographic, without giving anything close to a game that demographic would enjoy.

I can summarize the plot of this game in one sentence:

Your sister is a lesbian

reviewText:
In my most humble opinion, avoid playing this game at all cost.

This game is a prime example of how game journalists/critics are paid off to give a positive review. And also, proves the fact that the feminist media would go lengths to support a game which markets their interests.

Now to the short review.

Pros:
- Interesting premise
- Feels a bit scary from time to time.
- Doesn't hold the hand of the player to find clues or solve mysteries.
- Stuff to read that reminds the player of the 90s.

Cons:
- The story becomes predictable and boring during the early stages of the game.
- You do not feel any emotional impact when the game ends.
- Most of the interactable objects are useless and serve no purpose.
- Cliche LBGT theme.
- Can be finished in 30 minutes.

I would not recommend this game to any of my friends, unless they are interested in just reading stuff in a game with a whole lot of walking around. But, then again, I would recommened them a book instead. ^_^

reviewText:
Gone Home is a game beckoning players to solve its mystery. The moment the player walks into the empty house he or she is drawn in by the stillness of the vacant home. So begins a search to figure out where everyone has gone. The search never leaves the house, but the house is incredibly large and tightly-packed with subtle clues and objects to flesh out the plot. Gone Home doesn't require the player to do any more than explore, so if you're looking for anything more than a story-driven exploration game I'm afraid you may be disappointed. However, Gone Home commits to what it does, and it's that commitment that makes it a wonderful game.

On paper the story would seem lackluster, but it's the feeling and voice-acting of the narration of notes littered around the house that help give the game life. You begin to see that all the characters involved are deep and relatable even though you will never lay eyes on them. As you sift through all the belongings of your family you'll become closer with these people that have a lot more going on than you realize. It makes you wonder how much someone could get to know you just by going through your own home. As creepy as it sounds, Gone Home is a game that makes the player think about how these relationships are affecting each other, and ultimately affecting the end portion of the story.

Honestly, it's the sound design of Gone Home that heightened the experience for me. The sounds of an empty home during a thunderstorm were oddly chilling even though I knew I had nothing to fear. The crisp dialogue is perfectly cast, and the actors did an amazing job. This is one of those cases where great writing and acting come together to create something truly great. The soundtrack, however, really hit home for me. It's beautifully done comes in at just the perfect time for emphasis to what's happening in the story. I have the soundtrack on my phone as we speak, which is only something I do with the my favorites.

I love simple walking simulators that allow you to relax and enjoy a great story. Gone Home is well made, and there's a lot of love in it. If you enjoy a good story with relatable characters and a little exploration, you should pick this one up. However, be warned that Gone Home only lasts a couple hours unless you REALLY dig deep into the environment. As much as I love it, I would suggest getting it at a discount.

reviewText:
Why are you exploring this large empty house? Mostly to figure out what happened to your sister. But the story is dull and it doesn't tell what happened in the past through the environment like it's supposed to.  It's narrated to you through your sister's voice... when there is no clear way to explain why you are able to hear it (you can turn this off, but the game becomes even more boring because it feels emptier and lifeless).

The biggest weakness in this game is that there are no characters to interact with and nothing for you to do with the information you find. This is a step back from other great adventure games like Blade Runner and The Last Express. Those games put you in a role where understanding the perspectives of the other characters was very useful to your end goals and would dramatically affect your actions/decisions. Thus, I actually gave a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• about what happened and went looking through every single piece of the environment to make sure I didn't miss anything.

Not impressed at all.

reviewText:
Gone Home excels brilliantly at what it set out to do. Which was (incase you failed to notice) to create a short piece of environmental storytelling about a stressed out family against a 90's backdrop. Because of the setting, the game can be treated like a time capsule of sorts.

You explore an empty house, read a lot, listen to diary entries from a young woman coming to terms with her sexuality, look at zines, listen to Corin Tucker sing empowering feminist punk, etc.
You are likely to either adore this game and hold it dear to you, or discuss with your friends how much you hate it, and how much of a joke it is.

Due to the nature of exploring a family home devoid of people, the game leaves a lot to your imagination. If you are anyone like me, when you enter a character's bedroom you are likely going to sit around wondering what times the owner and her girlfriend shared there. You will sit around in the basement wondering what the punk show you are reading about was like for everybody involved.
That's why I personally like this game, how it flawlessly puts you in a state of melancholy, reading about these fantastic experiences as you, the player, roam around this big empty house alone with a bittersweet ambient soundtrack twanging away in the background.
These people were your family. Your sister has grown up into her own woman, your parents are in the process of rekindling their marriage after heavy difficulties, and your father's career is looking up after all.

Maybe im biased because im a girl who loves the culture spawned by the Riot Grrrl movement. Who knows. Either way this game stands alongside Thief: TDP and Rule of Rose as my three most beloved games.

reviewText: I went into this completely blind, only knowing that it had recieved tons of positive press and was devoloped by members of the extremely underated sequel to the original Bioshock.  After completing it I cannot understand why it has garnered the praise that it has.  I can appriciate a Dear Esther style exploration game that is simply ambient story telling, but what we have here is a poorly written, preditcable story that tries its hardest to achieve emotional resonance with the player whilst simultaneously having the (literal) depth of a high school freshman's diary.  All the while the game baits the player with red herrings that are far more interesting than what is actually there.\n\nI went in expecting great things, and came out utterly disappointed.  I hope I enjoy their next project more than I did this one.

reviewText: You know those quiet moments in, say, a Bioshock or a Fallout?  Where you get to take a break from the action and just walk around somebody's abandoned house, collecting audio diaries and figuring out what happened here?  The poingnat, sort of sad story of exctly WHY this house is abandoned and free to be rummaged through by the likes of you?  If I'm being honest, those moments are among my favorite, so one of the Bioshock devs going indie and making a game consisting of literally JUST that scratches a definite itch for me.  People tend to criticize this as a non-game
date: and they're not completely incorrect.  If you rummage behind a bookcase, say, you won't find money or ammo, just a half-full bottle as a quiet indicator of how Dad is coping with his failed writing career.  It's short and on rails and there's not really anything you can do to change the outcome, but this game has so much heart and emotion going for it that I've got to recommend it.  The ending made me teary-eyed and, if it's the sort of thing you're into, it is absolutely chock-a-block with 90's nostalgia.  Get it on sale to avoid any buyer's remorse over the brevity, but do get it.

reviewText:
Lesbians 10/10

Seriously though, you can listen to a Talyor Swift song (and pretend shes singing about a girl not a boy) and get most of the story here.

New girl moved to a new school and life is so hard and no one gets me! Oh turns out im a lesbian and im totally going to run away with this chick I have known for like 3 months and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• my parents they dont get me!

The graphics are alright but nothing to WRITE HOME about... Ha. You would think that only having to design 1 house would mean that the devs would put more details in the game and re use less things. It would seem this family loved their dressers and bookshelves so much that they bought them same exact ones and scattered them through the house!

They also have the same 'random clutter of letters and papers' that they use over and over. The clothes in the draws are downright laughable. Seriosuly. Google them. They have a few tapes and such you can put in and listen to but seeing as my taste in music isn't ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, I pulled them out and burned them with fire. (In my mind)

There are a large number of letters/notes that are written in what I like to call 'doctor's writing'. Which means that you cant bloody read them. A very important feature is missing from this game that hurts the expirence a great deal. That would be the ability to transfer messages on letters and such to a simple typed format overlayed over the note for people that dont want to take 3 years the break the code of what these people are writting.

It also suffers from to many narritives. You have about 5 stories going on at once that you are piecing together and it gets a tad confusing trying to keep names together as the diary entries only track Sam's letters and no one elses. In fact it seems you learn more about everyone else. Almost nothing is learned about the playable character other than we went on a trip to Europe and places and we are 3 years older than our sister.

There are very little physics to speak of. You can pick up and throw a few items in the game but the physics are some of the worst I have seen in a while.

To top of the insult we have the game bearly clocking in at an hour for someone that hasn't played it before and read most of the notes that werent complete chicken scratch. There isn't any replayability for this either. That means you are paying a Hamilton for an hour. I would say you are better off just buying a Taylor Swift album which will last longer, gets the same message accross, and at least is a nice voice to listen to. (I know that was the second time I mentioned her but this story just made me think of Taylor Swift so damn much.)

For what its worth the voice actor for Samantha does a pretty good job and does bring a little emotion to an otherwise cringeworthy story. Thats about the only good I can say though.

Also who just walks into their parents house and goes through all their ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•? Wouldn't a normal person just go to bed or wait for someone to come home?...Or Go home rather... Ha....

reviewText:
I wasn't quite sure what I was getting into when a friend let me play Gone Home.  I bought the game shortly afterwards.  If anyone questions videogames as art, or as a method of story telling beyond simply 'shoot the enemy' then they should play Gone Home.

If you simply want a game that is about shooting or blowing things up then this isn't for you... if you want a great story then buy it and enjoy discovering one piece by piece.

I can't express how much I want to discuss this game, but I also don't want to ruin it for anyone, so let me end on the note that this game knows exactly what feelings it is trying to evoke and it delivers.

reviewText:
A disclaimer is in order: This is not a game. The only meaningful choice is whether you continue to explore, or stop. There are no opponents, and the only obstacles are a handful of locked doors, the keys to which appear as you progress. Rather this is a work of digital fiction, a set of character studies told through the letters and keepsakes that they have acquired, through the exploration of a virtual world and through connections in the mind of the observer.

Without actually including any of them, the story presents us with several multifaceted cast members and the problems they face in life, work, love and family with a respect that feels at odds with an inherently voyeuristic aspect of the situation. The way it manages to touch on sensitive and dark issues tactfully, and with compassion even for those in the wrong, reflects a meaning of ‚Äòmature‚Äô that more mainstream games often overlook.

There are some flaws: a bit of railroading and one illogically locked door; an overuse of some props and inconsistent decisions about what is or isn‚Äôt interactive; and an occasional disconnect between those props, and sections of the story. None of which should impede anyone who didn‚Äôt lose interest in the first paragraph.

reviewText: A short, enjoyable tale about family, friends, and lovers. You take the place of Katie, the eldest daughter of a family of four who has returned from studying abroad in Europe for the past year. You return home to an empty house your family inherited while you were away. In an FPS discovery/journey style game, you must locate and decode clues around the enormous house to find out what exactly happened to your younger sister, and where your parents are.\n\nIt is a gem of an indie game, and was enjoyable, heartfelt, and relatable from start to finish. I definitely recommend picking this game up for the unique experience, and don't be surprised if you finish it in a couple hours.

reviewText:
Definitely one of the greatest story-driven games I've ever played.  The developers have created a believable, realistic setting and storyline that completely captures the atmosphere of the game.  It's a really beautfiul game, though the price is a bit lofty.  Having played the game, I find that it is a truly great game, but $20 is a little bit pricy for 4, maybe 5, hours of gameplay, and I completed the entirety of the game in that time.  I believe I finished the story and found all the collectibles (there really aren't any) in the time period.  The replay value and price are a little disappointing, but the story and emotion make up for it.  Beautiful piece, but don't go in expecting traditional gameplay or length.  Worth the buy, but maybe when it's on sale.

Addition:
It's been two years since I wrote this review, I think, and it still holds true.  This game is one of the few that I can say affected me on an emotional level.  It isn't for everyone, though, that's for sure, and looking at it now, the storyline is a bit cliche, but to me, this game is beautiful.  And really, beauty is in the eye of the beholder, so what more can you ask?

reviewText:
This game received a lot of love from critics when it came out, initially resulting in an over 90% metascore. Most critics praised it for being unconventional, experimental, emotional and unique. While some gamers agreed, a large part of the user community didn‚Äôt seem quite as excited about Gone Home, calling it ‚Äúboring‚Äù, ‚Äúnot even a game‚Äù, ‚Äútoo short and still a waste of time‚Äù or simply ‚Äútoo expensive for the content you get‚Äù. Gone Home apparently is one of those love-it-or-hate-it games.

I‚Äôm also having a hard time calling narrative-driven games actual ‚Äúgames‚Äù, since there is hardly any gameplay or challenge to be found. All you can do is walk around, click on objects and crouch while you figure out the story. That‚Äôs why I also understand people who call it boring, because there is just not much happening on the screen. And yes, it is short; very short. Even searching the whole house and reading every letter and scrap hardly got me two hours of gameplay with a replay value close to zero. So yes, its standard price is way too expensive for the content you get, so I waited until it was on sale. And I didn‚Äôt regret the purchase.

At first I just really enjoyed that good old 90s nostalgia which made me immediately miss my own good old times. The overall atmosphere is pretty decent, although it might come along as to horror-y for a game that has absolutely no horror in it. Sometimes it gave me the impression to get jumpscared any minute, which just felt a little out of place for a love story. Since I want my review to be free of spoilers, I won‚Äôt give you too many details about the story itself. Let‚Äôs just say I found the story wasn‚Äôt as original or daring (when it comes to the topic of homosexuality) as some people said it would be. It‚Äôs just another love story in my opinion and love stories are not my cup of tea by any means. However, I still found it very touching at some moments. The monologues are very well written and the voice actress reading them with a beautiful voice and the fitting amount of emotion does a fantastic job in helping you imagine how things developed for the characters. Creating such an immersion without much actually happening on screen is something not many games can pull off.

I enjoyed this game a lot and I‚Äôll probably think about it for quite some time, but I still have to say that 20 ‚Ç¨ is just too much for two hours of gameplay. Gone Home might probably have prevented a lot of the hate it got if the price wasn‚Äôt so high in the first place.
So wait until it‚Äôs on sale and have a good time if:

-	You enjoy exploring an environment and unwrapping a story
-	You enjoy (love story related) emotions in a story
-	You enjoy reading and listening to monologues in a game
-	You don‚Äôt mind the lack of actual gameplay or challenges
-	You don‚Äôt mind a game being short

reviewText:
Definitely one of the greatest story-driven games I've ever played.  The developers have created a believable, realistic setting and storyline that completely captures the atmosphere of the game.  It's a really beautfiul game, though the price is a bit lofty.  Having played the game, I find that it is a truly great game, but $20 is a little bit pricy for 4, maybe 5, hours of gameplay, and I completed the entirety of the game in that time.  I believe I finished the story and found all the collectibles (there really aren't any) in the time period.  The replay value and price are a little disappointing, but the story and emotion make up for it.  Beautiful piece, but don't go in expecting traditional gameplay or length.  Worth the buy, but maybe when it's on sale.

Addition:
It's been two years since I wrote this review, I think, and it still holds true.  This game is one of the few that I can say affected me on an emotional level.  It isn't for everyone, though, that's for sure, and looking at it now, the storyline is a bit cliche, but to me, this game is beautiful.  And really, beauty is in the eye of the beholder, so what more can you ask?

reviewText:
This is an amazingly crafted game.

Coming home to an empty house, you are looking for clues as to where your parents and you sister is.
The game is both tense and horrifying as you slowly uncover the secrets thorugh (voiced)diary entries which is scattered thorugh the house.

The game managed managed to keep me playing the entire way through and the tension did not decline at all. The atmosphere and the story is going to keep you  going to the end.

The only downside to the game is the length, but they surprised me how well you can fit story in such a small space. I played for about 1,5 hours and i am sure you can uncover all the secrets of the game in 2-2.5 hours. The game might not be for everybody, but if you like story, tension and the urge to explore I strongly recommend this game.

To everybody who play this game, go slow and explore.

reviewText: Gone Home involves walking around and doing simple exploration of an old family house. reviewText: Not a game, more an interactive experience about the same length as a movie.  You can interact with hundreds of items in this fairly large house which has numerous hidden things to uncover.  All the set pieces are great and the game taking place in the mid 90s plays homage to many things from that time.  Also the story is mainly told besides all the notes, etc that you can read through the voice of your sister Sam's journals.  It's a wonderful emotional tale that pulls you in, although i might be biased as i myself was a teenager in the mid 90's.  It's hard to call it an adventure game as there aren't really puzzles per se that don't rely exploration, still it is an adventure and a game I can whole heartedly recommend.

--= So what's the fuss about?????=--
Recommend Rating: 2/5

Bad:  story isn't that good, way too expensive
//SPOILER ALERT// I WILL TELL YOU WHY I THINK THE STORY ISN'T INTERESTING

I do not feel intimate about the narrative. From the beginning it was quite obvious that the protagonist and her sister are in a sort of binary opposition. While the player is more of a socially-acceptable person, her sister has a lot of traits of marginal people in school, family and society. This is why I don't like this game. It was also incredibly short, I managed to finish it in almost two hours and that is an accomplishment for someone like me who explores every nook and cranny in every game I play. That is why my biggest issue with this game is the gametime compared to the pricetag, the two do not seem to balance each other out. reviewText: Amazingly well-paced, considering it's basically an interactive novel. Voice acting and music are top-notch. You are experiencing a primary story with multiple supporting narratives throughout. One thing I really loved is that (virtually) everything in the game is still accessable at later points, so you can backtrack and replay" or re-experience parts of the narrative. This is like flipping back to a favourite or poignant part of a novel. This is much more a literary experience than a "game" in that sense... though I'm sure all the reviews say that.\n\nTime to completion is 2 hours. There's probably some replayability - I think I missed a few things in Oscar's thread
date: for example - but I'm overall satisfied with the experience and probably won't play again for a long time. That said

reviewText: Gone Home was a bit of a disappointment to me. Going into the game I had high expectations based on the great amount of possitive reviews however, the game fell short. The story actually found in the game though, feels cheap, like it was written for and by a depressed pre-teen girl. As someone who is not in the pre-teen girl demographic I didn't find this story aproach worth my time and money. The game had a great potential to tell a deep, dark, mysterious story, maybe something along the lines of Dear Esther. Obviously this wasn't the goal of the creaters though, which explains why I was left dissapointed.
